item.title: Basic Monte Carlo
item.description: The intuition: Remember the (weak) Law of Large Numbers? Just a quick recap: if \(X_1,\dots, X_n\) are i.i.d. random variables from a distribution \(F\) with mean \(\mu\) and variance \(\sigma^2\), then the sample mean \(\bar{X}_n\) converges in probability to the population mean \(\mu\). Using more formulas, we can write the LLN as \[ \bar{X}_n = \frac{1}{n}\sum_{i=1}^n X_i \rightarrow \mu =\int xdF(x)\] as \(n\rightarrow \infty\). One way to look at this is that, if the sample size \(n\) is “close to infinity” (or more generally, if \(n\) is “large enough”), then we have \[\frac{1}{n}\sum_{i=1}^n X_i \approx \int xdF.
